choices.C: The physical location must be updated from none to the appropriate location.
choices.B: The network locale must be changed from none to the Charlotte locale.
choices.A: Join across lines is not supported with Device Mobility and must be disabled.
choices.D: The device must be added to the Device Mobility group.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The exhibit shows that the Device Mobility Group is already configured but the Physical Location is not.

Selected Answer: C
I think it should be C.

Configure a Device Pool for Device Mobility - Step 3
-----------------------------------
Under Roaming Sensitive Settings, assign the parameters that you set up in the previous device mobility tasks:
>> Physical Location - From the drop-down list, select the physical location that you set up for this device pool. Device mobility uses this location to assign a device pool for a roaming device.

>> Device Mobility Group - From the drop-down list, select the device mobility group that you set up for this device pool.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/12_5_1SU1/cucm_b_feature-configuration-guide-for-cisco1251SU1/cucm_b_feature-configuration-guide-for-cisco1251SU2_chapter_011.html#CUCM_TK_CC7C2AFB_00

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An administrator configured Device Mobility but is receiving reports that local calls are failing when a user takes their device from the RTP location to the Charlotte location. The administrator confirmed that the correct subnet is configured under the Device Mobility info page. In addition, the roaming device pool has the correct Device Mobility calling search space selected. Which configuration change resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
location is one of the roaming sensitive parameter.
If mobility is not correctly configured, devices are associated to wrong location so CAC can't work properly. This can brings to audio quality issue

Selected Answer: C
I'm going with C on this one. Even though the engineer updated the region for the remote site, the phones may still be using the DP/Region from the initial site they moved from.

questions.question_text: An administrator manages an environment with mobile users who commonly move between locations and take IP phones to remote sites. When mobile users are at one of the sites, users report issues with call quality, such as the audio cutting in and out. In addition, the affected area has a low bandwidth connection compared to other sites, so the administrator has put these devices in a region with an inter-region restriction of 8 kbps per call. Which feature must the administrator configure to mitigate the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D

questions.question_text: An administrator is configuring a new deployment using Cisco Unified CME. The SCCP phones register without any issues, but SIP phones are not registering. Assume that all other configuration is valid. Which code allows SIP phones to register to Cisco UCME?

discussion.content:
I'd say it's B and E. There is no such thing as "called party URI transformation"

See SIP Route pattern Configuration Setting:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/telepresence/tcs/7_1/admin/administration/tcs_7_0/cucm.html

Selected Answer: B
B. Partition of the SIP route pattern

The partition determines which devices (phones, gateways, trunks, etc.) have access to the route pattern. By placing the SIP route pattern in a specific partition and assigning appropriate calling search spaces (CSS) to endpoints, the administrator can control which endpoints are allowed to reach *.webex.com.
E. Destination SIP trunk of the SIP route pattern

The SIP route pattern must be associated with the correct SIP trunk that directs calls to Webex. Without this, the traffic will not be routed properly.
I'd say it's B and E.

Answer is B and E. There isn't any Called party URI transformation configuration section under the SIP route pattern configuration. There are both Calling and Called party transformations but they DON'T HAVE TO be configured for the sip route pattern to work.

Selected Answer: B
A and B are the only ones that make sense to me.

Selected Answer: B
Two items B and D

choices.B: partition of the SIP route pattern
choices.E: destination SIP trunk of the SIP route pattern

questions.question_text: An administrator is configuring Cisco UCM and the system to send *.webex.com traffic to a Cisco UCM Session Management Edition cluster. The administrator wants to limit which endpoints can reach *.webex.com. Which two items must the administrator configure for the SIP route pattern? (Choose two.)
A support engineer is troubleshooting a voice network. When conducting a search for call setup details related to calling search space issues, which trace files should be investigated?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer : A
When you look into the Cisco CallManager traces, this line displays when a phone attempts to make a call:
Digit analysis: match(fqcn="2001", cn="2001", pss=":Internal:No-International", dd="")
'cn' stands for the calling number. In this case, it is 2001.
'pss' stands for partition search space, and has the information about the partition contained in the CSS assigned to the phone.
)
